name: NPR
text:
Trevor Milton is resigning from Nikola, a startup working on hydrogen-powered big rigs, after he was accused of fraudulently exaggerating the viability of some of his company's technology.
https://t.co/4vixnwgugb

name: NPR
text:
RT @KQEDarts: In this episode of #Rightnowish, stick 'til the very end to hear East Bay poet Victor Harris recite one of his favorite poems that speaks perfectly for our times right now. 

LISTEN ➡ https://t.co/7p5ZBPYH95 https://t.co/3m1c2Vh3Fn

name: NPR
text:
The pandemic has disrupted all kinds of supply chains — including the one that leads to the landfill.

Residential trash has increased. Some sanitation workers have gotten sick or had to quarantine. And it's not easy to find replacements.
https://t.co/kiUYPZBN4O

name: NPR
text:
RT @npratc: The coronavirus has killed nearly 200,000 people in America — far more than in any other country. It's not clear exactly how many of the dead are health care workers. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, how the pandemic is affecting the entire health care system.
https://t.co/gtqlADEnuO

name: NPR
text:
More than 1,300 inmates have been executed by lethal injection since 1977.

Now, the method is being challenged in federal courts after evidence of pulmonary edema — which can induce the feeling of suffocating or drowning — was found in inmate autopsies.
https://t.co/2ry1mJstPK

name: NPR
text:
Young Americans favor Joe Biden over President Trump by 60% to 27%, according to a new Harvard poll.

The survey also found far more voters under the age of 30 say they'll "definitely" be voting, compared to 2016.
https://t.co/keudaGFAUs

name: NPR
text:
The family of David "Ya Ya" McAtee — a 53-year-old Black man shot and killed by a National Guard soldier while he stood in the doorway of his barbeque stand in Louisville, Ky. — is filing a wrongful death lawsuit. 
https://t.co/M6NMgbbKSH

name: NPR
text:
62% of Americans feel the Supreme Court vacancy should be filled by whoever wins the presidential election, a Reuters/Ipsos poll finds.

But just over an hour after Ginsburg's death was announced, Mitch McConnell vowed to press forward on a Trump nominee.
https://t.co/lsmcRSmQbk

name: NPR
text:
Striking withholds something incredibly valuable: worker’s labor. 

@nprcodeswitch explores resonances between two strikes: one by 1880s washerwomen in Atlanta and recent strikes in professional sports. https://t.co/t2JPZcoYgM

name: NPR
text:
Two GOP senators have said the Senate shouldn't take up the Supreme Court nomination before the election. If 2 more Republican senators also opposed the vote, Mitch McConnell would be unable to proceed.
https://t.co/nLEGNFVuJ5

name: NPR
text: Curtailing the time for conducting the census in the middle of a pandemic will lead to "fatal data quality flaws that are unacceptable," Census Bureau career officials warned in an internal document. https://t.co/xbFV1XGMu8

name: NPR
text:
Hy-Vee has announced that DSW shoe outlets are opening in 6 of its Minnesota grocery stores. Shoppers will be able to try on shoes — then order them online.
https://t.co/uGNpHVk9sZ

name: NPR
text:
The Rev. Robert Graetz—who organized car pools to help support Black workers during the Montgomery Bus Boycott—has died at 92.

He and his wife, Jeannie, faced KKK death threats and had their home firebombed twice for their civil rights work in the '50s.
https://t.co/pggWvHEDZV

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: Sen. Mitt Romney announced that he supports voting on a Trump nominee to fill the vacancy on the Supreme C… https://t.co/GntMM5PNLe

name: NPR
text:
This year, the RNC says it's planning to recruit tens of thousands of poll watchers to observe ballot counting — especially mail ballots — at clerk's and registrar's offices across key states.

A Democratic election lawyer says that's chilling.
https://t.co/BfipMu1NTf

name: NPR
text: Just two GOP Senators, Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, have said they oppose taking up Trump's nominee to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the election. https://t.co/LPLcUEmIP0

name: NPR
text:
Opinion: The chance to provoke an anxious and angry electorate for campaign cash has often proved stronger than something that once mattered a great deal to the American experiment: a sense of our democracy as a shared responsibility, writes Ron Elving.
https://t.co/QHLfrIM2YH

name: NPR
text:
NEW: Over 200,000 people have now died from COVID-19 in the U.S., reaching what was once the upper limit of some estimates for the American death toll.

Experts warn the toll could nearly double again by the end of the year.
https://t.co/2V3NGqw1TG

name: NPR
NPR
text:
The NFL has fined three head coaches $100,000 for not wearing face masks on the sidelines — a violation of the league's safety precautions during the pandemic.

The coaches' teams were also hit with $250,000 fines.
https://t.co/lcfu0IlUxW

name: NPR
text:
Sen. Mitt Romney has announced he supports moving forward with a Trump nominee to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court, less than two months before the election.

That all but assures Mitch McConnell has the votes needed to take up the nomination.
https://t.co/ELAFtlHA98

name: NPR
text:
As coronavirus cases surge in the U.K., Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced that pubs, bars and restaurants in England must close by 10 p.m.

He also encouraged people to work from home if they're able to, reversing a previous government position.
https://t.co/d4V0WBHMVF

name: NPR
text:
As the 2020 election nears, @MorningEdition wants to hear: What's keeping you up at night? And how do those worries factor into your political decisions this year?

Fill out the linked form, and an NPR producer may be in touch for an upcoming story.
https://t.co/h1Izsf9gIQ

name: NPR
text: RT @alinaselyukh: Shay Chandler did not plan to buy what seemed like the last full-sized refrigerator in all of San Antonio. But shortages are hitting all kinds of major appliances... Here's why 1/ https://t.co/wyK1XdIYXm

name: NPR
text:
"Unprecedented" gets used a lot when describing the presidential election in 2000. But what was unprecedented two decades ago is starting to look… quaint in 2020.

This year, election lawyers say, may be the most litigated election in U.S. history.
https://t.co/lOD8zWpAq8

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: On the latest @allsongs, @BobBoilen talks to @YusufCatStevens about his reworking of 'Tea for the Tillerman,' exploring how and why he's revisiting these songs with some updated lyrics and instrumentation 50 years after its initial release. https://t.co/blGMVg7Hwt

name: NPR
text:
Quick ergonomics check: If you're on a computer, is the screen you're reading this tweet on at eye level?

It should be.

Here are some expert tips for avoiding the aches and pains of a bad work-from-home setup.
https://t.co/tCd8FsCwpo
